awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Rodent-human Cohabitation and Disease Transfer in Sedentary Human Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
Zoonotic diseases are those that are transmitted between humans and other animals, and they make up more than half of all infectious diseases in humans. Rodents are one of the richest sources of these zoonoses, yet both theoretical and empirical explanations are scant for why rodents have had such a great impact on human health and why some rodent species readily spread these diseases, while others do not. To better understand the epidemiological relationships that humans have with rodents, this dissertation research seeks to determine whether rodents that live in and around human homes (in an ecological relationship termed "commensalism") pose a greater threat to human health than wild rodents that are not commensal.  After determining this, the research team will investigate hypotheses for how the behavior and ecology of different rodent species influence patterns of coexistence with humans.  Doing so also will allow the researchers to propose an underlying cause for rodent commensalism, whether mainly for shelter and protection, or for access to food.

In order to maximize both the quantity and quality of data, the research will focus on rural populations in central Kenya, where over twenty endemic rodent species overlap with humans in a single habitat and show varying degrees of infection with zoonotic pathogens.  This diversity in rodent species and pathogens is unparalleled within the United States, and it provides an ideal natural setting in which to identify generalizable effects of commensalism on disease transmission. To determine differences in infection due to commensalism, the doctoral student researcher (Collin McCabe, under the supervision of Dr. Richard Wrangham, Harvard University) will capture rodents within homes and in nearby undisturbed habitats. Blood will be drawn from these animals, and these samples will be sent to a lab in the United States for zoonotic pathogen detection. The researchers will then assess the risk-taking behavior of the animals and also will evaluate their diets to determine the most likely explanation for these rodents' cohabitation with humans. 

By defining the patterns of infection and exposure among free-living rodents and humans, results of this research will suggest whether wild or commensal rodents present a bigger disease risk to humans, and by understanding the factors that influence commensalism, public health agencies can focus control efforts on the most likely areas of human-rodent overlap. In today's highly connected world, the health concerns arising from new disease outbreaks are truly global. Thus, by contributing to awareness and control of zoonotic outbreaks abroad, this study also will contribute to American health security.

por.por_cntn:
Rodents are common pest species known to inhabit human homes throughout the world, and they are also reservoirs for a multitude of human diseases; they have held both of these roles throughout much of human history. For his dissertation, "Behavioral determinants of pathogen risk across scales," Collin McCabe studied what specifically it is that drives some rodents to live with humans while others avoid human settlements in favor of wild habitats.  He also surveyed these rodents for the parasites and pathogens they carried, to propose an explanation for how their infection status and proximity to humans interact to create specific disease risks for these humans.  The research was supported by this NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant.

During the funding period, McCabe spent 10 months in central Kenya trapping rodents in and around human settlements. These sites and the study area in general were chosen because of recent transitions of villages in the area from nomadic pastoralist camps to sedentary agriculturalist settlements. Such transitions likely mirror those seen in the Fertile Crescent, where some of the first archaeological evidence of rodent avoidance was also discovered, ~10,000 years ago, around the advent of agriculture. He worked in collaboration with 16 different villages and 8 independent wildlife conservancies to discover general trends of rodent distribution, which proved to be fairly even in species abundances between wild and settled areas, although rodent communities were typically more diverse in wild habitats.  He found that storage of grain was, surprisingly, not a good predictor of rodent abundance in agricultural homes, and that rather, the rodents were more abundant in villages that were built closer to wildlife preserves. This result suggests that control measures which may be successful in decreasing rodent invasions into similar villages should emphasize maintaining larger buffer zones between settlements and wildlife preserves.

McCabe also studied the role that rodent behaviors under selection may play in their invasion of human settlements and their infection with various parasites and pathogens.  Building upon previous findings that domesticated animals tend to be more curious and playful, he looked for signs that these cohabiting rodents would also be more curious.  He accomplished this by housing the rodents after trapping and then conducting common laboratory behavior tests on the animals to gauge their levels of curiosity. Contrary to what he originally predicted, McCabe found that rodents captured in homes tended to be less curious than their wild counterparts- an outcome attributable to the fact that, after establishing their niche within homes, rodents may become more reserved as a means of self-preservation. This decrease in curiosity also translated into fewer parasite infections and lower parasite richness (the number of distinct parasite species infecting an animal) among home-living rodents in comparison to wild species- a predictable outcome of spending less time exploring their environment and coming into contact with fewer novel pathogens.

In conclusion, McCabe and his team found that house-dwelling rodents tended not to be drawn to human settlements by cached food resources, were less curious than their wild counterparts, and carried fewer pathogens with lower parasite richnesses.  All of these results point to a conclusion that wild rodents may pose a greater threat to novel pathogen spillover and infectious disease emergence than is often recognized. Such findings also suggest that an increase in disease surveillance of wild populations of rodents may be the best way to mitigate disease risks from these populations going forward.

These results are not just relevant to central Kenya, but are also transferable to rodent control and disease surveillance efforts in the United States, where various rodent-borne diseases, including plague, Sin Nombre virus/hantavirus, and Lyme disease are maintained in wild populations, and typically infect humans through interactions with these wild rodents or their ectoparasite vectors. Thus, the efforts and results of this study have far reaching implications not only for global health, broadly considered, but also for national public health and health security.

In addition to its intellectual results, this project has also produced various physical and online resources accessible by the public. These include: 280 rodent museum specimens from 16 species, housed at the Harvard University Museum of Comparative Zoology; type specimens of all parasites collected from these rodents; a blog detailing the methods and experiences of conducting this research in the field; and publicly accessible datasets of all findings from this study, available on McCabe's academic website.

Additionally, over the course of this project, various capacity-building and training opportunities were made available to various collaborating parties. Four Kenyan researchers were trained in field collection and safe handling of rodents, field sampling for pathogens, and animal housing/husbandry, while four American undergraduates were trained in medical parasite prevalence diagnostics, which in both cases will help to build capacities in each country to surveil and respond to future rodent-borne disease crises.
